newsitem.title: POLAND: First Polish link of Russian gas pipeline opens.
newsitem.headline: First Polish link of Russian gas pipeline opens.

text.p: Russian and Polish Prime Ministers Viktor Chernomyrdin and Wlodzimierz Cimoczewicz on Thursday opened the first Polish section of a giant pipeline which will supply western Europe with Russian gas.
The 107-km section, linking the German border and the western town of Lwowek, near Poznan, will allow for the first transport of Russian gas to reach Germany this year.
"This is a small beginning of a huge venture," Chernomyrdin said at the opening ceremony in the village of Zebowo, outside Lwowek.

This section, built at cost of $145 million, will later become part of the double pipeline able to carry 67 billion cubic meters of gas annually across 4,200 km from the Siberian Yamal peninsula to Germany in the year 2010.

"The opening of this section marks not only a turning point in the supply of the Polish economy in gas, but is also a crucial factor for the whole of Europe in the connection of its gas pipeline system," Poland's Cimoszewicz said.
The whole Polish section will measure 665 km and cost between $2.1 and $2.4 billion.

It will be build and operated by Europolgaz, in which the giant Russian Gazprom has a 48 percent stake, Poland's state-owned Polskie Gornictwo Naftowe i Gazownictwo 48 percent, and Polish-Russian firm GazTrading four percent.
Europolgaz is in talks with 19 financial institutions offering to finance the construction of the remaining part of the Polish pipeline.
Poland will eventually receive about 14 billion cubic meters of gas from Russia for up to 25 years through the Yamal pipeline, under an agreement signed earlier this year.
It will cover more than half of Poland's gas consumption in the year 2010, when the Yamal gas pipeline is expected to become fully operational.
Polish consumption, which rose to 10.5 billion cubic meters in 1995 from 9.6 billion in 1994, is expected to reach between 22 and 27 billion cubic meters in 2010.
Natural gas currently accounts for about 8.5 percent of Poland's energy supply but its share will increase to about 10 percent in future.
